title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [23 october 1871]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [23 October 1871]
text: MondayMy dear walti got your letter on saturdaySaturday and got those you sent through the week i am pretty well except a bad cold was hoarse this morning but am somewhat better now Jeff left the pills and i think i will take some to night to see if it wontwon't break up my cold i had a hurried letter from jeff last week he says after living upside down for some weeks they have concluded to stay where they are and the house is being fixed all nice that matty is quite smart and things goes on very good in his department) minne marysmary's daughter and her husband called here last saturday afternoon they were married on wensdayWednesday they are stopping at st nicholus s hotelSt. Nicholas Hotel new yorkNew York and on saturdaySaturday evening helen price came here and and stayed till yesterday sundaySunday her mother is quite complaining with her old complaint they think rather hard of your not writing to them as her mother wrote to you while she was in the country and never heard if you ever received it) well walt i beleivebelieve i will write the annoyances i had last week the first was little georgeys coming here and wanted money for his mother i give him a little change and as i supposed he wanted it for himself as edd said he had a boy waiting for him outside loo wanted me when she was here to find out when jimsjim's birth day was so i wrote a little note and sent it by george for nanc to write it down and i beleivebelieve it was the next day nanc sent a boy here with a letter and said she was on the street the night before and dreadful to read) the boy said it was a strange boy she said he must wait for an answer i told the boy i was sorry for her but i had no money to help her she said in the letter i could take george if i wanted too so saturdaySaturday night georgey came again after money he was very ragged but i had none to give i think he is very bad boy indeed i think the saturdaySaturday night he wanted it for himself) well after i had been so annoyed with the letter and georgey sgeorgey's coming) i had a letter from mr Heyde he had said in a former letter he was going to dispose of some pictures at montreal he said this in his last letter he hadenthadn't sold them yet he was waiting to hear more particulars and that he had got 150 dollrdollar from the bank and gave his note for three months and if he had to take up any more money he should come straitstraight to brooklynBrooklyn) well walt i had to laughflaugh i thought that was worse than nanc i dontdon't suppose he had any idea of coming but it seemed to me so rediculousridiculous he didentdidn't say whether he was coming to live on me or what he was going to doo he said han was very well now he wants her to come here he says) i dontdon't pay any attention to his rediculous writings) O walt i like to forget i got Lady Judith and i get all the papers you send and all the money and it comes very good sometimes i tell you my dear Walt dontdon't worry walt about my trouble with nance and georgey it did make me feel bad and sorry for her but perhaps there was no truth in itthis is quit a letter waltgood biethe weatheweather is almost totoo warm here Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [23 October 1871]
